elements.content: Organic-molecular magnets based on a metal–organic framework with chemically tuned electronic and magnetic properties have been attracting tremendous attention due to their promising applications in molecular magnetic sensors, magnetic particle medicines, molecular spintronics, etc. Here, we investigated the magnetic behavior of a heterojunction comprising a ferromagnetic nickel (Ni) film and an organic semiconductor (OSC) 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (F4-TCNQ) layer. Through the magneto-optical Kerr effect (MOKE), a photoemission electron microscopy (PEEM), X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), we found that the adsorption of F4-TCNQ on Cu(100)/Ni not only reverses the in-plane magnetization direction originally exhibited by the Ni layer but also results in enhanced magnetic ordering. Furthermore, the cyano group (CN) in adsorbed F4-TCNQ was found spin-polarized along with conspicuous charge transfer with Ni. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggest that the experimentally found spin polarization originates from hybridization between the CN group’s π orbitals and Ni’s d band. These findings signify that the hybrid states at the organic–ferromagnet interface play a key role in tailoring the magnetic behavior of interfaces. For the case of the F4-TCNQ and Ni heterojunction reported here, interface coupling is an antiferromagnetic one.

elements.content: One exciting development in modern technology is the advancement of nanoelectronics capable of manipulating electrons’ charge and spin degrees of freedom. By encoding information with the spin states and accessing it through the external magnetic field, the utilization of solid-state devices has enabled the information industry and logic technologies to go through rapid progress since the late 20th century. Particularly, a fundamental unit known as spin valve is used to control the flow of spin-polarized carriers through its sandwich structure: two ferromagnetic electrodes separated by a nonmagnetic spacer. Considering that the performance of a spin valve, i.e., the value or polarity of the magnetoresistance (MR), depends strongly on the spin injection efficiency from the magnetic electrode and the spin coherence in the nonmagnetic spacer, it was proposed that the organic materials capable of providing a longer spin coherence lifetime could be good alternatives for the spacer. In the efforts to improve the spin injection/filtering efficiency, however, prior knowledge of electronic states at the organic–ferromagnetic interface is required so that functionality tailoring is possible.

Introduction

One exciting development in modern technology is the advancement of nanoelectronics capable of manipulating electrons' charge and spin degrees of freedom. By encoding information with the spin states and accessing it through the external magnetic field, the utilization of solid-state devices has enabled the information industry and logic technologies to go through rapid progress since the late 20th century. Particularly, a fundamental unit known as spin valve is used to control the flow of spin-polarized carriers through its sandwich structure: two ferromagnetic electrodes separated by a nonmagnetic spacer. Considering that the performance of a spin valve, i.e., the value or polarity of the magnetoresistance (MR), depends strongly on the spin injection efficiency from the magnetic electrode and the spin coherence in the nonmagnetic spacer, it was proposed that the organic materials capable of providing a longer spin coherence lifetime could be good alternatives for the spacer. In the efforts to improve the spin injection/filtering efficiency, however, prior knowledge of electronic states at the organic-ferromagnetic interface is required so that functionality tailoring is possible.

elements.content: A transition metal with unfilled 3d shell electrons displays spin ordering at high temperatures and shows a novel spin reorientation transition (SRT) from in-plane to perpendicular magnetization as the film thickness increases. This unusual dependence of the magnetic behavior on the thickness is interpreted as a competition among the magnetoelastic volume anisotropy, the shape anisotropy, and the sum of the surface plus interface anisotropies due to the pseudomorphic growth. Apart from the spin anisotropy modulated by the surface and the interface, an adsorbed layer (adlayer) on the transition metal can also modify the spin texture, i.e., spin polarization, spin ordering, or exchange coupling, to tune the magnetism. Through the modification of the interface, the surface might alter the magnetic textures; it is thus important to clarify the magnetic texture near and beyond the region of pseudomorphic growth that makes a varied contribution to affect the magnetic response in the spintronics. On the other hand, tetracyano-based molecules such as TCNE and TCNQ have been known as promising organic materials to form metal–organic frameworks and organic/molecular magnets at room temperature for novel spintronic applications. Among these, the fluorinated counterpart of TCNQ, i.e., F4-TCNQ, is a strong acceptor molecule with high electron affinity, resulting in distinct charge transfer and hybridization states at the organic/metallic interface. Previous studies revealed that superior magnetic coupling and significant spin polarization are induced at these ferromagnetic–organic heterojunctions. Based on these, we investigated an F4-TCNQ-tailored Ni surface in the present work to get more details of magnetization variation and how the magnetic coupling between F4-TCNQ and Ni films affects spin injection and transport at the organic–ferromagnetic interface.

elements.content: In this paper, we report that F4-TCNQ tailors the magnetic exchange coupling of a Ni film on Cu(100), represented as Cu(100)/Ni. F4-TCNQ was implemented to modulate the magnetism of Cu(100)/Ni in a different magnetization direction that is governed by pseudomorphic growth. The first region of interest that we sought to explore was near the critical thickness of ferromagnetic Ni films, which is important for the surface and interface anisotropy of a Ni film. The second attractive topic is far above the critical thickness at which the film grows beyond the pseudomorphic region. We deposited F4-TCNQ on a Ni surface and investigated the magnetic coupling between F4-TCNQ and Ni, as well as the molecular bonding and electronic structure. We studied the interface properties of Ni/F4-TCNQ with various Ni layer thicknesses using the magneto-optical Kerr effect (MOKE), photoemission electron microscopy (PEEM), X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and calculations with density functional theory (DFT). The experimental results demonstrate conspicuous charge transfer between F4-TCNQ and Ni, which produces significant long-range magnetic ordering through strong magnetic exchange coupling at the hybrid ferromagnetic–organic heterojunctions.

The surface morphologies of Cu(100)/Ni and F4-TCNQ on Cu(100)/Ni with different deposition rates ranging from 1.5 to 6 Å/min were analyzed using atomic force microscopy (AFM), and the roughness (Rq) results are summarized in Figure S1. We recorded PES at U5-spectroscopy beamline (BL) 09A2 in the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC), Taiwan. The magnetic hysteresis loops were measured on detecting the MOKE signals in both longitudinal and polar configurations using a He–Ne laser. XMCD-based PEEM images were recorded with circularly polarized light, in opposite photon polarizations (σ, −σ), that illuminated at an incident angle of 25° with respect to the sample surface plane to acquire domain patterns with magnetic contrast at NSRRC BL 05B2. To examine magnetic coupling at the F4-TCNQ and Ni heterostructure, element-specific XMCD spectra were recorded at NSRRC BL 11A. After the samples were fabricated, they were kept in an isolated portable UHV chamber and moved to BL 11A1 to conduct XMCD experiments without exposure to air. The XMCD measurements can be obtained by changing either the magnetization or helicity of the X-rays. In this work, the XMCD spectrum was obtained to change the magnetization. In XMCD measurements, the samples were placed between two coils of an electromagnet that generated a variable magnetic field (H) collinearly. The incident beam was illuminated at an angle of 30° with respect to the sample surface plane to record X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) in the total electron yield (TEY) mode. The samples were rotated relative to H to obtain the in-plane (θ = 0°) and out-of-plane (θ = 90°) magnetic anisotropy-dependent XAS spectra; θ denotes the angle between the sample surface and H. The XMCD signals of the Ni L-edge, F K-edge, and N K-edge were recorded near 300 K for in-plane and out-of-plane configurations with alignments of fixed photon helicity to the applied magnetic field H: ±300–500 Oe. The XMCD spectra were derived from the intensity difference between H – and H + (H + – H –). The dichroic ratio is defined as the intensity ratio [(I H – – I H +)/(I H – + I H +)], which is proportional to the strength of spin polarization (SP), to reveal the strength of SP in the samples. DFT calculations were performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation program (VASP) using PAW pseudopotentials and plane waves with a cutoff energy of 600 eV at the GGA-PW91 level. The precise structure used in the DFT calculation is a single atomic Ni layer on five layers of Cu(100); each layer includes 20 metallic (Cu or Ni) elements. The Cu(100) substrate plays a role in constraining the structure of the Ni layer surface in the (100) facet and Cu lattice constants. DFT calculations of a single atomic Ni layer were also compared with those of the Ni(100) facet slab, and the results are shown in Figure S5.

Upon capping Ni surfaces (8 and 9 ML) with F4-TCNQ (3 Å), a remarkable enhancement of the in-plane coercive field along the easy axis was obtained with L-MOKE (a,b). In the P-MOKE measurement, the coercive magnetic hysteresis loops become appreciable after F4-TCNQ capping on Ni at 8 and 9 ML (d,e). elements.content: To understand thoroughly the variation of the magnetic textures, we recorded, in the TEY mode, XMCD spectra of the Ni L-edge for Ni (8 and 9 ML) with and without adsorption of F4-TCNQ (0 and 3 Å) on applying an in-plane magnetic field, as shown in the upper spectra of a,b. The external magnetic fields were ±500 to ±300 Oe for magnetic measurements. Such external magnetic fields can make the corresponding samples magnetically saturated. After deposition of F4-TCNQ, Ni films (both 8 and 9 ML) displayed an enhancement of the in-plane XMCD signals. Noticeably, the XMCD spectra of the Ni L-edge for bare Ni (9 ML) expressed a positive signal for L3 but a negative signal for L2. A contrary dichroism behavior to one with F4-TCNQ atop means that the Ni magnetic moments almost reverse after contact with F4-TCNQ. Moreover, the intensity of the XMCD spectrum of a Ni/F4-TCNQ (3 Å) film increased relative to that of the bare Ni film; the dichroic ratio of Ni (9 ML) was estimated to be 3.81% for bare Ni and 6.14% for the deposited Ni-F4-TCNQ film. For comparison of a bare Ni (20 ML) film and a Ni (20 ML)/F4-TCNQ (3 Å) film, the in-plane dichroic ratio also increased to 6.67% with F4-TCNQ atop (see c). These results suggest that the in-plane magnetic moment of the Ni film is strongly increased after the adsorption of F4-TCNQ.

elements.content: XPEEM was performed to evaluate the orbital hybridization and related micromagnetic behavior of Ni (Θ ML)/F4-TCNQ (0 and 3 Å), Θ = 8, 9, and 20 ML, which are nearby and above the first SRT (∼9.5 ML), respectively, with the latter displaying out-of-plane magnetization. XMCD-based PEEM imaging was acquired based on the XMCD contrast of the Ni L2 and L3 absorption edges at opposite photon helicities σ and −σ. We inspected the magnetic domain of Ni (8 ML) that shows paramagnetism below the critical thickness of ∼9.5 ML according to XPEEM, as shown in a. The PEEM images of the Ni L-edge show no magnetic domain for both positive σ and negative −σ photon helicities, consistent with the observed paramagnetism of Ni (8 ML) on Cu(100). After capping with F4-TCNQ, the appearance of a magnetic domain, as shown in a, indicates that the ferromagnetic ordering was evidently improved through the strong coupling between F4-TCNQ and Ni, coinciding with the MOKE and XMCD results. In b, a ladder sample with half-deposited 9 and 20 ML Ni exhibits a significant change of the Ni domain contrast after F4-TCNQ atop in the 9 ML region, whereas no obvious change is observed in the 20 ML region. As the PEEM images are recorded at an incident angle of 25° with respect to the sample surface to acquire the in-plane domain, it is predictable not to observe a clear magnetic domain with PEEM in the region of Ni (20 ML), which prefers out-of-plane magnetization. Compared to the domain images in the ∼9 ML Ni region, as marked in a red square acquired before and after F4-TCNQ deposition, we found that a large portion of the dark contrast domains, which were dominantly distributed across the region, was severely shrunk and became replaced with a large portion of the bright contrast after F4-TCNQ adsorption (b). The reverse changes on shrinking the dark contrast domain and enlarging the bright contrast domain after F4-TCNQ deposition hence indicate antiferromagnetic coupling between the organic layer and ferromagnetic Ni; the changes also resulted in flipping the shattered domains into a greater domain, which was also observed in the system of F4-TCNQ on Co. As a result, the combination of the above XMCD and MOKE results, which expressed increased in-plane magnetization and ferromagnetic ordering, indicates that a long-range magnetic order is enhanced with a strong antiferromagnetic coupling between Ni and F4-TCNQ heterojunctions. Even pristine Ni (20 ML) showed stronger out-of-plane magnetization after deposition of F4-TCNQ. Moreover, no lateral domain flipping was noticed in comparison with the region of Ni (9 ML). Such magnetic variations and patterns for Ni (9 ML)/F4-TCNQ and Ni (20 ML)/F4-TCNQ structures indicate that in-plane magnetization was significantly enhanced and reversed on the Ni layers, especially for a film near the critical thickness.

elements.content: To understand thoroughly the magnetic coupling for F4-TCNQ in contact with Ni, we measured the XMCD spectrum of F4-TCNQ (3 Å) on Ni (9 and 20 ML) for the N and F K-edges. From these results, we observed no F XMCD signal at Ni either 9 or 20 ML in both in-plane and out-of-plane measurements, but the CN (π orbital) XMCD signals are evident for in-plane magnetization and less for out-of-plane magnetization (c,d), especially for F4-TCNQ (3 Å) on Ni (9 ML). Nevertheless, the CN XMCD signal of the Ni (9 ML)/F4-TCNQ (3 Å) sample is positive, whereas the corresponding Ni L3-edge XMCD signal is negative. This result indicates that an antiferromagnetic interaction was excited between the upper F4-TCNQ and the underlying Ni, corresponding to a shrinking of the dark contrast domain in the PEEM image after deposition of F4-TCNQ on Ni (9 ML). The N XMCD signal was found also for the Ni (8 ML)/F4-TCNQ (3 Å) sample (Figure S4). These results indicate that the CN (π orbital) in F4-TCNQ has planar spin polarization upon its adsorption on Ni. The dichroic ratio of spin-polarized CN at 399 eV is estimated to be ca. 1.33% for 9 ML Ni and 0.38% for 20 ML Ni. That is, for F4-TCNQ on Ni (9 ML), the N XMCD signal was more obvious than that on Ni (20 ML). The details regarding the variation of the spin polarization of CN for Cu(100)/Ni/F4-TCNQ are discussed in the following of DFT calculation.

elements.content: The adsorption structure of F4-TCNQ on Cu(100)/Ni, denoted Cu(100)/Ni/F4-TCNQ, was initially optimized. As shown in a, the most stable adsorption has four CN groups in F4-TCNQ bonded in parallel to the surface Ni, indicating that the bonding arose through the CN π bands (not the N lone pair) with the Ni d bands. The density of states (DOS) values of the bonding orbitals were further analyzed and are shown in b. Before the adsorption of F4-TCNQ, surface Ni had an asymmetric DOS for spin­(α) and spin­(β), yellow shadows, whereas bonding π and antibonding π* bands of CN (cyan shadows) had symmetric spin­(α) and spin­(β) and were located near the Fermi level. After adsorption, the valance d band of Ni interacted with the similar-energetic CN π* band and back-donated electrons to the empty π* orbitals. As a result, the asymmetry of spin­(α) and spin­(β) was altered. The asymmetry of Ni in-plane d xy and d x 2–y 2 , which are the major bonding orbitals, was examined in detail and is shown in c,d. Before adsorption, the Ni in-plane d orbitals have obvious spin-down spin­(α–β) near the Fermi level (dashed lines in c), implying that Ni had more spin­(β) electrons distributed at higher energy. Interestingly, spin­(α–β) reversed and showed an evident spin-up after adsorption (solid lines in d). The reverse of spin­(α–β) can be rationalized from electron back-donation during adsorption; the higher-energetic spin­(β) back-donated more electrons to the CN π* orbitals and became less than spin­(α) electrons. We also examined spin polarization on integrating spin­(α–β) in the total energetic range, as shown in e. The bar chart indicates that the spin polarization of in-plane d xy and d x 2–y 2 orbitals of Cu(100)/Ni/F4-TCNQ (solid bars) was larger than, and opposite to, those of Cu(100)/Ni (dot bars), as observed in the experiment (). We also examined DFT calculations on the Ni(100) facet slab with Cu lattice constants and compared it with the above single-layered Ni model. The results are summarized and plotted in Figure S5. The behaviors of spin polarization (spin­(α–β)) on those two models have a similar trend that the reversed disparity is observed upon F4-TCNQ adsorption.

elements.content: With F4-TCNQ capping on Ni, especially near the critical thickness, 9 ML, the results of MOKE, XMCD, and DFT calculation demonstrate a significant increase of the in-plane magnetic moments of the Ni layer. The XMCD spectra and DFT calculations also suggest the induction of ferromagnetic ordering in the presence of F4-TCNQ through hybridization at the interface. Based on the previous case of Co/F4-TCNQ, which shows conspicuous charge transfer between Co and the CN group of F4-TCNQ to induce magnetic coupling, we employed XPS to characterize the chemical state of F4-TCNQ on Ni films of various thicknesses, as reported in . The N 1s XPS spectra of both Ni (9 ML)/F4-TCNQ (0–15 Å) and Ni (20 ML)/F4-TCNQ (0–15 Å), as shown in a,b, respectively, exhibit three major signals; the binding energies (BEs) are 398.2, 399.3, and 400.6 eV. By analogy with the results for F4-TCNQ and TCNQ reported on other metal surfaces, we assigned the N 1s signal at 398.2 eV to an anionic species resulting from charge transfer (in direct contact with Ni), the signal at 399.3 eV to noncontact CN or neutral F4-TCNQ (multiple layers), and the signal at 400.6 eV to a satellite or shakeup structure. The N 1s core-level spectra of F4-TCNQ (θ = 0–15 Å) on Ni (both 9 and 20 ML) presented similar variations of signal features and intensities. The signals centered at 399.3 and 400.6 eV were perceptibly escalated on initial adsorption and became saturated upon increasing the F4-TCNQ thickness through the presence of electron transfer with metallic Ni at a thin F4-TCNQ layer. c,d displays the corresponding XPS core-level spectra of the Ni 2p3/2 signal for F4-TCNQ (θ = 0–15 Å) on Ni (9 and 20 ML), respectively. On the Ni (9 ML) surface, the Ni 2p3/2 core-level spectra were deconvoluted to a single line at a BE of 853.0 eV. The line underwent a slight positive BE shift (853.1 eV) and maintained that same value even with F4-TCNQ at increasing thickness. In contrast, the Ni 2p3/2 signal of Ni (20 ML) exhibited almost identical positions of signals, indicating that the invariant signal might arise mainly from free electrons originating from a large portion of underlying Ni layers. Although the Ni 2p3/2 results exhibit that no obvious charge transfer occurred at the interface of Ni and F4-TCNQ, the additional signal at 398 eV of XPS N 1s strongly indicates that CN π electrons of F4-TCNQ hybridize with the Ni layer in contact in both Ni cases (9 and 20 ML). The dependence on the thickness of chemical and electronic structures revealed by XPS is neither observed nor correlated with an enhanced magnetic ordering. With DFT computation we investigated the mechanism of the F4-TCNQ induced magnetic coupling. The enhanced and reversed magnetic moment upon F4-TCNQ adsorption originated from electron back-donation from the valance d orbitals of surface Ni to the CN π* orbitals; the in-plane d xy and d x 2–y 2 orbitals back-donated more electrons from the higher-energetic spin­(β) to enhance and reverse the disparity of the two spins as well as their spin polarization.

Conclusions

With a knowledge of which anisotropies are important, we have attempted to vary, in a controlled manner, the direction of magnetization through the addition of capping layers. In this work, we tailored the Ni surface via F4-TCNQ near and far from the critical thickness of the Ni SRT, so that we can successfully visualize enhanced magnetic ordering and reversed magnetization. Our results showed that surface magnetization was enhanced and spin polarization was induced with an F4-TCNQ capping layer. Moreover, surface tailoring of the F4-TCNQ capping layer on Ni strengthened the in-plane magnetization for all studied thicknesses, which originated from the molecular pinning effect through hybridization with Ni via the CN group of F4-TCNQ. Such an interplay of proximity coupling in a hybrid heterostructure sheds light on engineering the exchange coupling to tune the magnetic texture and transport characteristics in molecular spintronics.

cln_elements.content: shows the hysteresis measurements of M vs H with longitudinal-MOKE (L-MOKE, upper part) and polar-MOKE (P-MOKE, lower part) intensities as a function of Ni film thickness ((a, d) 8 ML, (b, e) 9 ML, and (c, f) 20 ML) on clean Cu(100) and subsequently deposited F4-TCNQ (3 Å) atop. According to the M–H loops plotted in Figures S2 and S3 in this work, the Ni film shows the first SRT from in-plane to out-of-plane magnetization at about 9.5 ML and maintains that out-of-plane magnetization with the Ni thickness increasing to about ∼20 ML. These results agree well with previous work that demonstrates a similar transition thickness. Upon capping Ni surfaces (8 and 9 ML) with F4-TCNQ (3 Å), a remarkable enhancement of the in-plane coercive field along the easy axis was obtained with L-MOKE (a,b). In the P-MOKE measurement, the coercive magnetic hysteresis loops become appreciable after F4-TCNQ capping on Ni at 8 and 9 ML (d,e). The highly coercive hysteresis loops in both L- and P-MOKE after molecular adsorption on Ni films (8 and 9 ML) show that the ferromagnetic order is significantly enhanced relative to the original anisotropy. When F4-TCNQ was capped on 20 ML Ni, the in-plane coercive field showed remanence of almost 100%. This result is due to the limitation of the magnetic field supply that did not magnetically saturate the sample; no variation of hysteresis loops in L-MOKE (c) was observed. The out-of-plane coercivity was slightly increased after contact with F4-TCNQ, as shown in f. As a result, the enhancement of ferromagnetic ordering in the region near the first SRT is attributed to the surface modification of the magnetic texture by F4-TCNQ. As the Kerr intensity is proportional to magnetization, the MOKE results indicate that F4-TCNQ capping enhances the Kerr intensity, magnifies the magnetization, and thus alters the magnetic textures.

Results and Discussion

  shows the hysteresis measurements of M vs H with longitudinal-MOKE (L-MOKE, upper part) and polar-MOKE (P-MOKE, lower part) intensities as a function of Ni film thickness ((a, d) 8 ML, (b, e) 9 ML, and (c, f) 20 ML) on clean Cu(100) and subsequently deposited F4-TCNQ (3 Å) atop. According to the M-H loops plotted in Figures S2 and S3 in this work, the Ni film shows the first SRT from in-plane to out-of-plane magnetization at about 9.5 ML and maintains that out-of-plane magnetization with the Ni thickness increasing to about ~20 ML. These results agree well with previous work that demonstrates a similar transition thickness. Upon capping Ni surfaces (8 and 9 ML) with F4-TCNQ (3 Å), a remarkable enhancement of the in-plane coercive field along the easy axis was obtained with L-MOKE (a,b). In the P-MOKE measurement, the coercive magnetic hysteresis loops become appreciable after F4-TCNQ capping on Ni at 8 and 9 ML (d,e). The highly coercive hysteresis loops in both L- and P-MOKE after molecular adsorption on Ni films (8 and 9 ML) show that the ferromagnetic order is significantly enhanced relative to the original anisotropy. When F4-TCNQ was capped on 20 ML Ni, the in-plane coercive field showed remanence of almost 100%. This result is due to the limitation of the magnetic field supply that did not magnetically saturate the sample; no variation of hysteresis loops in L-MOKE (c) was observed. The out-of-plane coercivity was slightly increased after contact with F4-TCNQ, as shown in f. As a result, the enhancement of ferromagnetic ordering in the region near the first SRT is attributed to the surface modification of the magnetic texture by F4-TCNQ. As the Kerr intensity is proportional to magnetization, the MOKE results indicate that F4-TCNQ capping enhances the Kerr intensity, magnifies the magnetization, and thus alters the magnetic textures.
